text: Matthieu dear black city hello my needle
drops Anthony Fantino here Internet's
busiest music nerd gonna do an album
review it actually came as a result of a
comment this review is actually a
request from youtube user nice Ellis
Brown who said I do like that p-word
it's irresistible politeness so we're
gonna take a look at the new Matthew
Deere album black city this thing even
got the you're wrong I'm right stamp of
approval so I figured why not let's talk
about it
for those who are familiar with Matthew
Deere he's an electronic musician and
also one of the founders of the ghostly
international record label highly
recommended and this is his fourth LP
now what do you get on this album I
would just like to simply put it as
dance music dance music dance music
dance music it don't get much simpler
than that
beats synths sound effects and Matthew
dears very low chilli vocals but I
wouldn't say this LP blends into the
grey with every other dance music album
that I've heard thus far this year and
what makes it stand out is its mood its
atmosphere honestly for dance music it's
pretty dark it's like listening to neon
lights and leather bound pole dancers in
a futuristic city where it's dark 24
hours a day
not to mention everybody in this
post-apocalyptic city is very sexy and
dressed to the nines kind of like a
fashionista or something like that I
have to give it to matthew dior for kind
of creating a sense of place on this
album I think I really wouldn't fit in
in black city personally but still seems
like a pretty seductive
setting in terms of musical influences
this thing pulls from the early days of
techno the dance of your side of
post-punk disco music there's some
pretty ambient and shoegazing moments on
the
thing to it just subtly genre hops
without breaking character it's a feat
in and of itself that the last song on
this album a very morose very slow very
depressing track named gem doesn't feel
in conflict with a track that is kind of
a 180 little people which is 9 minutes
long and a total it's my main gripes
with this thing is that there's a lot of
repetition on this album though I would
say that's mostly because Matthew Deere
isn't really aiming for the headphones
isn't really aiming for the home stereo
on this thing but like I said earlier
the dancefloor so the repetition isn't
necessarily a buzzkill but for me what
can be a total buzzkill on this thing
are the lyrics words about monkeys big
black cars big black mansion it's okay
but I wouldn't say it's a problem every
track suffers from necessarily I wasn't
in love with every block in black city
but there was still enough standout
moments to make me want to give this
thing a decent too strong 7 a lot of
irresistible beats lush electronics
memorable vocals if you're in the market
for an electronic album that is going to
make you squirm uncomfortably in the
club then I would give you the go ahead
and visit black City as much as possible
again thank you to nice Ellis Brown for
the request you guys let me know what
you would like me to review next and let
me know what you think of this LP did
you love it did you hate it and why and
what would you have scored it anthony
Fantana Mathew dear black City forever
you
